rule_text: In the event of any inconsistency between this Specification and the LDA Apartment Typology Booklet, then the LDA Apartment Typology Booklet shall prevail.
The taxonomy and sustainability requirements set out in the Procedures Manual shall prevail over this Specification.
• If the Developer becomes aware of any inconsistency between the requirements set out in this Specification, it shall promptly inform the Technical Monitor.
The Technical Monitor may issue a direction to resolve any such inconsistency, and the direction shall be conclusive.

• The design of all apartments must meet the building regulations and relevant Technical Guidance Documents including the Sustainable Urban Housing Design Standards and the LDA Apartment Typology Booklet.

• The work shall comprise the whole of the labour and, unless otherwise expressly stated, all the materials necessary to form a complete mechanical and electrical services installation with such tests, adjustments, commissioning and maintenance as may be required to give effective and safe working installations to the satisfaction of the Client`s representative.
Irish Standards shall take preference in all cases.

If there is a conflict or inconsistency between such Standards and the other requirements of the Specification, then the Technical Monitor shall decide in his discretion on which standard takes precedence.
• The external façade and quality finishes shall be of the highest standard throughout.
• Facade finishes, brickwork, render and cladding materials must be consistent in quality across all elevations and avoid patching.
• All facade materials shall be robust and incorporate anti vandal measures where required.
• External building facades shall be designed to prevent future staining.
• External facades of a building must not provide a medium for fire spread.
• Care in brick-and-mortar selection and storage shall be incorporated to avoid efflorescence and any water staining.
• No timber shall be permitted in any part of any façade other than were used as a factory- made frame of an alu-clad timber window system.
• Vertical Services risers through roof must be fully insulated and weathered.
• SVP within amenity roof areas shall be designed and coordinated to prevent smells and risk of vandalism.
• The requirement for Fall protection systems and associated maintenance requirements should be avoided by ensuring roof parapets, parapet railings are a minimum height of 1100mm.

• Parapets shall be designed so they are fit for purpose, resist wind uplift, fall inwards away from the façade and have sufficient hangover to prevent staining to the building façade as well as preventing any water ingress to the building envelope.

• The waterproof membrane must be lapped up and under all window and door frames to maintain a continuous waterproof barrier and reduce risk of water ingress, in accordance with the manufactured guidelines.
• A minimum depth or projection of 1.5 meters is required for balconies, with a maximum projection of 1.8m.
• Balcony door thresholds shall be designed to prevent water ingress.
• Balcony finish floor level should be designed with a minimum raised 10mm lip min to the perimeter to reduce risk objects rolling off.

• The top of the handrail balustrade should be a minimum of 1100mm above finished FFL OR horizontal step on balustrade were falling from height, extra height should be considered to allow for site tolerances.
• Balcony Guarding should be constructed so that a 75 mm diameter sphere cannot pass through any openings in the guarding.
• Guarding and Railings to a minimum height of 1100mm should be provided to the inside of the parapet level or above any horizontal step, horizontal railings to be avoided.
• A minimum upstand of 150mm should be provided from the waterproof membrane layer to the underside of door threshold/weather seal to prevent water ingress in accordance with manufactured guidelines.
• The Developer must ensure a rainwater drainage system is provided to serve all roofs, terraces, and balconies.
The Developer must ensure that the drainage falls/gradients do not allow for any standing water to collect.
The rainwater system must have sufficient capacity to meet the requirements of the Building Regulation.
• Rainwater calculations shall be undertaken for all roof, terrace, podium and balconies areas to demonstrate compliance.
• Appropriate drainage must be provided to each balcony to prevent water egress to apartments/balconies/terraces below.
The contractor must ensure that the drainage falls/gradients do not allow any ponding or standing water to collect.
• Linear drains shall be installed at all external entrances and exits, bin store and plant room doors, ramps, carpark areas to prevent ponding.
• Windows must comply with the LDA Apartment typology booklet.

• External window frames throughout shall be of a proprietary hardwood, thermally broken aluminium or aluminium clad timber windows, double glazed (except where specifically required to meet regulations, or where following a specific Part L example, triple glazed).
• The window systems selected must exceed the NZEB performance requirements by a min of 10%.

• Apartment window heights should range from 2250mm to 2400mm subject to compliance with Technical Monitor requirements and be compliant with relevant planning, daylighting requirements and the LDA apartment typology Booklet.
Restrictors should limit the window opening to 100mm and then allow opening further, up to 90 degrees.
• The restrictor catches holding the window at 100mm opening shall be capable of being de-activated by an adult without the use of tools and shall automatically re-engage once the window is closed.
• Restrictor stays and locks shall not prevent escape in the case of a fire where required.
• Window cills shall be designed with sufficient hangover to prevent staining to the building facade.
• Windows that are required to be opaque should be opaque glass.
• Doors must comply with the LDA Apartment typology booklet.

• External doors throughout shall be thermally broken aluminium to match the window system, double glazed (except where specifically required to meet regulations, or where following a specific Part L example, triple glazed).
• The external door systems selected must exceed the NZEB performance requirements by a min of 10%.
• Wind restrictors and protective bollards should be provided to amenity roof gardens doors required to swing outward and any areas where there is a risk of wind catching the doors.
• Wall vents in façade brickwork shall match the colour of the brick.

rule_text: • Wall vents shall be designed to brick sizes and align with brick work set out and align vertically and horizontally on elevations and be coordinated between the Architect, Engineer, Mechanical Engineer, Fire Consultant and Developer.

rule_text: • Apartment wall vents shall be designed to align with window jambs where possible.

rule_text: • Waterproof tanking, full height around bath/shower area and full extent of floor with 150mm upstand to all walls.
Approximate size 600 x 300mm.
Approximate size 600 x 300mm, Tiling on all walls around the bath/shower area, full height for the perimeter of the area concerned.
Tiled splash backs above WHB should cover the width of the basin at a minimum height of 300mm, including tile trim and silicone seal.
Approximate size 660 x 450 x 145mm.
• Shower/ Bath screen, chrome plated hinged 6mm glass screen with safety glass in accordance with BS6262.
Approximate size 450mm x 550mm.
• All SVP should be vertical from ground to top floor level and where they penetrate a roof, they shall be designed in accordance with the Building Regulations.
• All SVP Systems must be fully air tested and flush tested.
• All materials and workmanship throughout shall be of good quality and fit for purpose.
• All proprietary materials must be used strictly in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions and recommendations.
and must be submitted to the Technical Monitor for comments prior to manufacture.
• Kitchen Worktops, Laminated worktop required to comprise 28mm particle board with square edge and abs lipping OR high-quality laminate equivalent e.g.
20mm Ice Crystal Solid Surface to be heat-resistant to 180°C.
Fire blanket should be 1.2m by 1.8m in size.
• Kitchen tap, 100mm Height Spout, Chrome Single Lever Mono Mixer Tap; Securely Mounted to sink.
• A minimum 100mm splash back upstand to all kitchen counter tops to match the counter should be provided with mastic sealant at interface between splash back and wall to match the worktop.
Co-ordination between 100mm splash back and window height required.
• Pot Drawer infill: High sided drawer, no pot pins • Wall units 380mm deep as per room data sheet.
• Height of wall unit as per room data sheets: 500mm above countertop.

• As part of commissioning and snagging, developer should ensure that the appliances are all tested and operational, user manuals should be included in the Safety manual and Warranties must be included for a minimum of 12 months (except where longer is indicated below).
▪ Adjustable top basket ▪ Overflow & leakage protection ▪ A++ energy rating ▪ Three-year warranty ▪ Maximum noise level 49db(a) o Washing Machine
• Ensure provision of a min 1.5-2m jump back from electrical consumer unit in accordance with M&E Employers requirement specification.
o 450 mm width of 6 adjustable shelves o two proprietary chromed steel hanging rails and brackets.
• Apartment internal and external walls shall be designed to be compliant with TGD E – Sound.
• Internal apartments partitions walls shall provide an internal stud wall sound insulation performance of a minimum dB rating of 45dB when tested on site.
Impact, air-borne and flanking transmission shall be designed out and consideration to use of acoustic wall vents shall be given.
Where pre-cast concrete walls are not used, party walls to be timber or metal stud system partitions, generally with 12.5mm plasterboard each side or equivalent.

Where party walls are pre-cast concrete walls with a fine finish, a skimmed and painted finish is acceptable, where a fine finish is not provided the wall should be lined with timber or metal stud system, generally with 12.5mm plasterboard or equivalent.

Where not needed to meet such performance requirements, internal partition walls are to be uninsulated timber or metal stud system partitions, generally with 12.5mm plasterboard each side or equivalent.
• Where possible, structural columns, RC walls should be no thicker than 200mm to keep the width of separating compartment walls to a minimum.
• All stud partition walls shall be taped, jointed and skimmed in accordance with the manufacturer’s guidelines.
• Service Voids below 800mm should be avoided to avoid the requirement for additional smoke detectors, associated access hatches and maintenance.
• Apartment Entrance Door, 44 mm thick solid core flush door, paint grade with factory primer and hardwood lipping to all sides.
• Internal Doors, 44 mm thick solid core flush door, paint grade with factory primer and hardwood lipping to all sides.

• Internal apartment door swing to ensure doors can open the minimum of 90 degrees or more if required to comply with relevant ECW regulation requirements and avoid clashes where multiple doors open in close proximity.
• Skirting, 100 x 19mm Painted moisture resistant MDF square profile skirting.
• Architrave, 75 x 25mm Painted moisture resistant MDF square profile architrave.
• Window Boards, 25mm moisture resistant MDF bullnose profile window boards.
• Kick plates required to both sides of all common area doors.
• Push plate required to push side of common area doors.
• All window ironmongery must include the following: o Easy clean hinges and handles capable of being safely latched in a partially open position.
• Each ground level main entrance, including the car park entrance, shall have an intercom base unit with audio capability to each apartment, linked to the access control system.
• Door entry systems, intercoms shall be vandal resistant.
• The apartment unit shall only be able to remotely open the respective main entrance core door.
• Apartments shall not be able to open the car park entrance gates.
• Access control is required to the following areas as a minimum: • Ground level core entrance doors to apartments linked to the intercom base unit.
• The following general requirements apply for keys: o All keys shall be provided batched and sorted.
Resident’s keys shall be provided in a separate folder to the landlord keys.
o For each Unit the following set of keys shall be provided: ▪ No.
3 key fobs per Unit shall be provided for each door with fob access, each fob should be clearly labelled to identify which access door it serves.
3 keys shall be provided for each piece of communal service equipment such as fire alarm panel, automatic opening vents (where applicable)
o Difference in FFL between two different areas/finishes should be less than 10mm within apartments.
o Carpet to be minimum 8mm thick, heavy-duty, dark grey colour and resistant to staining.
• 8-10mm timber laminate flooring that is water resistant for up to 24 hours, with acoustic underlay.
• Format: 1380x193 wide x 8-10mm thick laminate board.
• 8-10mm timber laminate flooring that is water resistant for up to 24 hours, with acoustic underlay.
o 32mm HD system with steel operating chain.
• Individual letter boxes shall have a maximum aperture size of 260mm x 40mm.
16mm Recessed Black/Grey Aluminium base with pvc bridging strips.
A mat should be provided that is at least as wide as the entrance door, 1.5m deep and is flush with the adjacent floor surface.
• Flooring, 600x600mm Blue/Grey Tufted Carpet Tile with Stain Protection (Heavy Traffic) 60x35mm Aluminium Alloy Stair Nosing 5-7mm with Min.
Approximate lift car internal dimensions 1100 X 2100mm.
• Internal doors, all doors are to be 44 mm thick solid core flush doors, with vision panels as required, selected timber veneer and with hardwood lipping all round.
100mm satin finished stainless steel ball bearing hinges and mortice lock.
• Skirting boards, 100 x 19mm moisture resistant MDF square profile skirting.
• Architrave, 75 x 25mm moisture resistant MDF square profile architrave.
• Window Boards, 25mm moisture resistant MDF bullnose profile window boards.
• Kickplates, all doors to be fitted with brushed stainless steel kickplates minimum 150mm high full width of door leaf.
• Residential amenity areas shall be safe for use and not pose a hazard to the users, consideration should be given towards trips, slips and sharp edges.
• The signage style, appearance and locations are to be agreed with the Employer, in advance of producing a drawing package and must be in keeping with the overall scheme design and colour.

rule_text: • Layout - Refer to Civil engineer and ‘‘Institute of Structural Engineers Carpark Design’, 2023 guidance document) • A minimum 2.2m Meter clearance is required within all basement, under croft parking below services.
• A Minimum 2.6m areas within all basement, under croft parking below services for accessible parking.
o All access routes for all plant shall meets all access requirements for the room & plant equipment and be safe and easily accessible.

• The Developer shall note and comply with the Local Authorities detailed requirements in relation to Project Construction and Demolition Waste Management Plan Requirements noted in the scheduled conditions attached to the Planning permission.

• Materials shall be suitable for the purposes of the works stated in or reasonably to be inferred from the contract documents, and the best of their respective kinds and all articles and materials are to be not less than those standards contained in the latest EU Standards or relevant Code of Practice where such exists.
• Materials should be easy to maintain, durable and must not require frequent maintenance.
• Materials and products shall be proposed to ensure that the lifecycle costs of the development and maintenance requirements are all kept to a minimum.
• Materials should be easy to maintain, durable and must not require frequent maintenance.
• Materials and products shall be proposed to ensure that the lifecycle costs of the development and maintenance requirements are all kept to a minimum.
• Specialist automated gate designer will be required to complete and issue site specific Automated gate Design Risk Assessment to demonstrate automated gates do not pose a risk.
• All external metalwork shall be treated with a hot-dip galvanized coating.
• The selected paint system for metalwork shall be devised specifically for application onto galvanised steel and applied by a specialist applicator to prevent flaking of paintwork to mild steel.
• A single source complete paint system shall be used for consistency of paint colour and finish.
• All UD shall be designed to be flexible to allow provision for future changes to comply with all future UD future requirements such as level access showers and conversion of bathrooms to ensuites.
• The Developer shall provide a mechanical services installation which is fit for purpose and which meets the requirements of this Specification.

• The words “complete mechanical services installation” shall mean not only the major items of plant and apparatus described in this Specification, but also the incidental sundry accessories and components necessary for the complete execution of the works and for the proper and safe operation of the installation, whether or not these sundry accessories or components are mentioned in detail in the LDA Requirements issued in connection with the Contract.

• The pipe work shall generally run within locations that shall not affect the buildings visual approach to concealing pipe work, reducing space available within the apartments and the building, or limit access to pipe work for maintenance.
• Pipework shall not run embedded in concrete.
• Pipework shall generally be concealed, running within accessible voids and risers.
• Pipework shall generally drop where indicated on the room data sheets or neatly at the corner of rooms where it is not possible to easily conceal the pipework.
• Pipes shall be sized with a maximum pressure drop of 300Pa per m run and pipe velocities shall be held below 1.5m/s.

• Ductwork shall generally run within the locations that shall not affect the buildings visual approach to concealing ductwork, reducing space available within the building, or limit access to ductwork for maintenance.
• All pipework within plant rooms shall be finished with aluminium cladding (except for valves which shall all be fitted with Velcro jackets).
• All exposed pipe and ductwork within carparks where applicable shall be finished with polyisobutylene for protection.
Clear and concise labelling required of all services including direction of flow and corresponding dwelling number shall be provided for all waste pipes/overflows/drainage /water services etc.
Where a service serves more than one dwelling it shall be routed within landlord areas only.

For example, horizontal runs of drainage pipework serving an apartment cannot run within the ceiling void of the apartment below and mechanical services shall be prevented from running through ground floor retail and commercial spaces.

• The Works must comply with Legal Requirements including the following: o The Building Regulations o The Building Control Regulations (BCAR) o Safety, Health and Welfare at Work Act o The Asbestos Regulations o Local Authorities By-Laws and Regulations o Water Supply Authority’s requirements o Electricity Supply Authority’s requirements o Gas Supply Authority’s requirements o Fire Officers’ Requirements o IS 10101 National Rules for Electrical Installations • The Works shall be carried out in accordance with the requirements and regulations of all relevant local authorities, utility providers and statutory bodies who have any jurisdiction over the Works, or the manner in which they are to be constructed.
• An electronic operating and maintenance manual and associated “as installed” drawings archive shall be procured from a specialist documentation company by the Developer.
• This manual must be prepared in advance of practical completion and handed to and demonstrated to the Employer on completion of the building.
• The Safety File shall be compatible with and be fully integrated with the Employer’s standard Safety File software platform.
• The design shall include for the drainage of waste from floor gulleys within plant rooms.
• The design shall include the drainage of waste from air stacks and other points where rainwater is likely to gather.
• The system shall comply fully with the requirements of EN 12056-2:2000 and Part H of the building Regulation Technical Guidance Documents.
• In addition to complying with the performance specification, the waste system shall comply with the following:

• The waste system pipework shall be installed using the minimum pipe work lengths and minimum number of fittings necessary to carry away all discharge from appliances and provide quality access for cleaning purposes.
• All pipework shall be routed to the below ground system with falls at a minimum in compliance with the regulations and appropriate to ensure no blockages.

• Drainage on upper floors shall connect separately to the below ground drainage serving the ground floor and basement (where applicable) and shall not route through ground floor non-residential areas.
• All drainage runs shall be concealed within voids or boxed out where natural building voids do not exist.
Removable access hatches shall be provided in boxings or panelling to provide access to all access doors within the system.
• No branch pipe shall run more than 3m without the use of an associated vent pipe.

• The Developer shall install or procure the installation of the complete above ground soils and wastes installation including associated vent and overflow pipe work, and all connections to outlets and equipment.
• The exact setting out of ground sockets to suit the actual sanitary wear or other equipment to be installed shall be the responsibility of the Developer.

• The Developer shall be responsible for the coordination between the drainage drawings for all areas in good time relative to the construction activities and shall advise the Technical Monitor if any changes to the location of ground sockets are required prior to their installation.
• The Developer shall include for: o Provision and installation of all traps o Final connections to all sanitary ware and equipment o Fitting of all overflow pipe work required.
• Air admittance valves shall not be used.
• WCs shall be provided by the Developer with internal siphon overflow protection which shall prevent the use of the WC in the event of an overflow.
• Overflows shall be provided from all tanks and drip trays shall be provided below all tanks with dedicated overflows.
The overflows shall terminate to a gully external of the plant room so as they are easily visible to management and capped with a mesh to prevent vermin accessing.
• All safety valves outlets shall be piped to a safe location in copper pipe work.
Routing of safety pipe work shall be clearly planned to avoid trip hazards.
• Where floor gulleys are required, the Developer shall provide stainless steel removable cover gulleys.

• All SVPs (Soil and Vent Pipes) shall be uPVC with all branch pipes manufactured from polypropylene except where SVPs run through ground floor retail or commercial space, and these shall run in cast iron.

• The Developer shall be responsible for including all access points required to safely clean and maintain the complete soils and wastes installation without requiring destructive intrusion into the system.
Access points shall include access doors above flood level at every 2nd floor in all SVPs.
Access doors shall be provided at least once on every 2nd floor for branch pipework and at all changes of direction where wastes run within ceiling voids.
Access shall be provided at the end of all float pipes.
• All trap connections shall be screw on traps to allow ease of removal.
• The firefighting lifts shall be fitted with pneumatic gulley’s that shall only open on receipt of a double knock from the fire alarm.
The control panel shall detect a gulley stuck open condition and report it to the BMS and shall receive a double knock signal from the fire alarm.
• All condensate drains shall be fitted with flap non return valves to create a seal without requiring the manual topping up of traps.
• All condensate drains shall be fitted with flap non return valves to create a seal without requiring the manual topping up of traps.

• All SVPs and Vent Pipes shall run 300mm above roof and terminate in cowls except where it is within 3 metres of a fresh air intake or openable window/door/louvre where it shall be required to run 900mm above the roof and terminate in cowls.
Water services to each dwelling shall be easily isolated from within the dwelling itself or above the ceiling directly outside the entrance door.
Water softening shall be of the magnetic softening type where provided.
The tank shall be accessible with suitable clearance overhead to open the access hatch beyond 90degrees.
• All Pipework shall be insulated with foil backed insulation.
All pipework within the basement and plant rooms shall be treated as external and insulated to external thicknesses outlined within this specification.
Valve jackets provided with Velcro fixings shall be provided on all valves within the plant room.
Pump bodies shall be provided with removable insulation covers to manufacturer’s recommendations.
• All exposed pipe within the carpark shall be finished with polyisobutylene for protection.
• Outside plant areas, pipework shall run concealed within risers or accessible voids.
• Pipework shall only be un-insulated for short final runs where insulation may be exposed to damage.
Any exposed and un-insulated pipework shall be neatly painted to an agreed colour.
• All valves outside plant areas shall be insulated with specific valve insulation products like jackets or sleeves.
Any valves located externally shall be arranged with their spindles below the pipe to allow draining.
Insulation used on external pipe shall be suitable for use in wet environments and shall not hold water.
• Pipework shall run neatly and parallel to other pipes and building elements.
Pipework shall not share common insulation.
Pipes of differing temperatures shall be separated by a minimum distance of 50mm clear of insulation.
• Ballofix valves shall be provided at all final connections to outlets and equipment connections.
Lever operated isolation valves shall be provided internally to allow the isolation of any external taps.
These isolation valves shall be located at within reach or fully accessible risers to allow ease of routine isolation.
Shower valves shall be easily accessible.
• Valves shall be of quarter turn lever operation in preference to hand wheel valves to ensure speed of operation.
• Isolation valves shall be provided on all branches, all dwelling branches shall be capable of being isolated.
Isolation shall also be provided as indicated on the drawings and schematics.
Automatic air vents shall be provided at any high points.

• The Developer shall be responsible for ensuring that meters are correctly sized for the load and shall ensure that the meters are installed within the ceiling of the circulation space directly outside the apartment and to the manufacturer’s instructions and in particular the manufacturer’s recommendations in relation to the straight run of pipe preceding and following the meter.
Meters shall be load tested on completion and the results of the testing submitted to the client’s representative.
• All systems shall be tested, flushed, and chlorinated prior to connecting to the public mains water network.
A signed certificate of testing and flushing shall be provided by the Developer on completion of the works.
A cross contamination dye test shall be carried out and demonstrated to the Technical Monitor.
This die test shall cover each water system.
• Lead based solder shall not be used on any of the water systems, irrespective of what they are serving.
• Before practical completion a water quality test must be taken, using a sample of water from ten points selected by the client’s representative.
Samples must be collected after 24hrs without flow in the system.
The water shall be tested, and the test results shall be returned to the Client’s representative with a comment on the suitability of the water for use as potable water.
The results shall include readings for lead and copper content.
Where selected, blanked off drinking water points shall be opened for testing purposes.
Testing shall be to SI 122 and shall be carried out by an NSAI accredited test lab.
Test results shall comply with SI 122.

• All water systems shall be boosted where buildings exceed 3 stories (or where low- pressure mains necessitates it) and pressure reducing valves shall be used to retain appropriate pressures to fittings on the lower floors.
All tanks shall be two compartment tanks to ensure ease of cleaning.
The supplies to the two halves of the tank shall be controlled through motorized valves and level sensors with local valve controllers provided.
The valve controllers shall ensure equal top up to both tank sections and shall include a maintenance feature to allow the system to continue working on one half during the cleaning process.
• All water boosters shall be variable speed and contain triplex pumps.
• The Developer shall be responsible for all water pipe work inside the building.
• All pipework used shall be certified for use in portable systems and shall be WRAS approved for drinking water.
The piping system used shall have a 50-year expected lifespan and shall have a pressure rating of PN16 up to 70o C.
• Pre-insulated pipework may only be used within the dwelling up to a maximum pipe diameter of 26mm and shall be required to comply with the Part L insulation requirements.
Water services pipework outside of the dwellings or of greater diameter shall be installed in copper i.e., within circulation spaces, risers and plant spaces etc.
Where pipework is exposed or has potential to be damaged within the dwelling it must be installed in copper.
• Where adhesives are used, they shall be certified for potable use and shall be a different colour to the pipework so that the use of incorrect adhesives can easily be identified.
• Provide all bracketing as required to support all pipework to manufacturer’s recommendations.
• A clearly labelled mains isolation valve shall be provided in the plantroom that houses the water tank(s), sized to meet the complete water load for the building.
• A check meter shall be provided within the plant room, on the mains water supply in order to record water usage information.

• The mains water shall also connect if required to the fire hose reel tank and the recycled water tank / irrigation tank where applicable and separate metered connections shall be used to each of the tanks.
• Hot water shall be provided to all hot water outlets from the hot water heating systems.
• The hot water generation system shall be designed and installed to achieve the following: o Generate adequate quantities of hot water to serve the fittings within the building.
o The hot water capacity shall achieve a minimum of 200 Litres at 40o C when tested against the EN16147 standard.
o Provide backup electric resistance heating to cover the full load and the heating elements shall automatically enable if the system is unable to maintain water temperatures.

• The development shall comply with the Employer’s requirements relating to the taxonomy and the sustainable use of water, as set out in the Procedures Manual and subject to such requirements, the following maximum flowrates shall be used for the

water appliances, and these shall be attested by product datasheets, a building certification, or an existing product label in the Union and be provided to the Technical Monitor at Practical Completion: a) Wash hand basin taps, and kitchen taps have a maximum water flow of 6 litres/min.

• Water conservation is an important element and particular attention shall be paid to the following: o Ensuring excessive flow rates do not occur, particularly from fittings on the lower floors where pressures are higher (pressure reducing valves shall be used to control excessive pressure on the lower floors.) o Ensuring all meters are accurately commissioned and proved to be working correctly.
• As part of its tests leading up to Practical Completion the Developer shall carry out a leakage test and confirm that there is no flow through the system during a 24hr test period.
This shall be designed to dump the content of the tank if it becomes stagnant.

The design shall ensure that the tank is not topped up while purging and that the valves used (which are unlikely to be opened in normal use, are cycled occasionally to prevent seizing) • Tank and pumps shall comply with BS/EN 12845.
• Quality access shall be provided to all systems and components for maintenance.
• A legionella protection system shall be designed and supplied from a provider that specialises in legionella flushing for flushing of the cold and mains water feed.
The specialist provider shall carry out testing and commissioning of the system.
The specialist provider shall sign off on works completed with the system provided.
This system shall operate using a control valve linked to a temperature sensor.
Control valve shall be a self- closing valve to prevent leaks from occurring after operation.
System shall be located at the end of the final run, control valve liked to a temperature sensor shall activate when cold water temperature exceeds 20o C.
If water temperature within the cold-water pipe work reaches or exceeds 20o C the temperature sensor shall send a signal to the control valve to open and drain a portion of the water from the system.
This will drain water from the main run and tank, the water shall then be topped up via the mains water break tank.
All valves used within this system shall be suitable and compatible for use with potable water.
System shall be capable of operating under temperature-controlled water change and time-controlled water change.
In the event the building is left dormant the system shall operate on a time-controlled water change, draining stagnant water on a time interval.
System shall operate on a master / slave system, in case of an error, an optical signal occurs and a transfer of the alarm signal to a BMS is possible by dry contact.
Control valve and temperature sensor shall be linked to a local control panel for operation.
Fault signal shall be sent to BMS in the event an error occurs in the system.
• The Developer shall provide a heating system with ensures that the Employer can achieve the taxonomy and sustainability requirements set out in the Procedures Manual.

In addition, the Developer shall provide a system which is in accordance with the following: o No reliance on fossil fuels o Zone and control of heating to provide an efficient and comfortable environment; and o Valve isolation such that isolation of circuits / sub-circuits / branches shall have minimal disruption to the remaining units.
o Heating system that complies with the current Part L requirements • The heating system loading shall be designed on the basis of an external air temperature of -5o C.
• All systems shall remain protected from damage due to temperatures with external temperatures as low as -15o C.
• The Developer shall develop a heating strategy for the building, which shall be submitted for review as part of the Design Review Procedure set out in the Development Agreement.
The Developer shall thermally model the simultaneous load, which will be used to provide appropriate and optimised heating zones within the apartments and building.
• Space heating shall be provided throughout using a variety of modes and systems dependent on the particular application.

• If there is a situation where comfort cooling is proposed, this must be fully integrated with the heating system to ensure efficient control of the systems with an appropriate dead band (typically 20C), between the control settings or physical interlocks to prevent simultaneous operation.
design team must exhaust all other passive avenues (orientation, external shading etc) before recommending mechanical / systems-based solution.
• The Developer shall provide good quality heat emitters, where appropriate, throughout the building.
Where panel radiators are provided, they shall be manufactured of a minimum of 2mm thick steel panels.
Low water content, heat exchanger type radiators shall be constructed of a minimum of 1.5mm thick folded steel casing totalling 3mm thick.
Radiators where provided shall meet I.S.
EN 442 and shall be provided with thermostatic valves.
Local control shall be provided for temperature adjustment in each occupied space to reflect differing user demands.
In areas where the occupancy is greater than twenty (20), the control of the room temperature shall be via a Building Management system.
• Internal design conditions must be achieved and maintained for all specified occupancy periods and shall accommodate planned out-of-normal hour’s use.
To satisfy these requirements, and to cater for the orientation and aspect of the building while maintaining conservation of energy, consideration must be given to system flexibility and zoning.
• All dwelling units shall have adequate valving to provide manual isolation of off-line units without interruption of service.
All required auxiliaries for the unit systems shall be provided.
• Isolation valves, shutoff valves, by-pass circuits, flanges and unions shall be provided on piping to equipment in order to facilitate equipment repair and replacement.
Equipment requiring isolation includes, (but shall not be limited to): heat generators; heat pumps; pumps; coils; terminal units; circuits; sub-circuits and heat exchangers.
Valves shall also be provided for major branches such as zones, floor levels and mechanical rooms.
Isolating valves, both flow and return, shall be provided on all circuits.
• Expansion vessels in the dwellings are to be easily accessible and shall not be located behind buffer tanks, heat pumps etc that would interfere with removal.
• The Developer shall ensure that the control requirements for the respective spaces are suitable to maintain good control from a comfort and end user point of view.
• The Developer shall ensure that horizontal distribution pipework routes are located in ceiling voids and vertical distribution routes are located in designated service shafts within landlord areas.
Surface pipework shall generally be avoided.
Where visible pipework is considered, reference shall be made to the Room Data Sheets and the buildings architectural aesthetics.
Access to all fittings shall be maintained.

• Heating pipework routed from a central plantroom to dwelling shall be black mild steel, to BS 1387, medium grade for diameters 80mm and below and heavy grade for diameters greater than 80mm, butt welded throughout.
• Heating pipework within the dwelling units shall be in copper.

• Heating pipework shall be sized on the basis of maximum pressure loss per linear meter as follows: o Heating pipework low loss header in heating plant room - 50Pa/m o Heating distribution pipework main distribution - 200Pa/m o Heating distribution pipework branch distribution - 150Pa/m • Space heating circuits shall be either externally weather compensated or constant temperature type.
• Each heating circuit shall be provided with an A-rated pump set complete with integrated variable speed drive.
• Isolation valves, shutoff valves, by-pass circuits, flanges and unions shall be provided on piping to equipment in order to facilitate equipment repair and replacement.
• Equipment requiring isolation shall include but not be limited to the following: boilers; heat pump units; pumps; coils; terminal units; circuits; sub-circuits and heat exchangers.
• Isolation valves shall also be provided for major branches such as zones, floor levels and mechanical plant areas.

• The Developer shall ensure that all heating pipework is insulated throughout with class ‘O’ foil back fibre glass insulation and where pipework is exposed or within a plant room it shall be finished with aluminium cladding.
• The Developer shall ensure that the space heating system is adequately valved to allow for future maintenance and the entire pipework distribution including valves are tagged and identified.
• All centralised circulating pumps shall be of the twin head in-line type complete with integrated variable speed controllers.
All circulating pumps shall be located internally within plant rooms.
External circulating pumps shall not be permitted.
The electric heater shall be an oil filled radiator with electric heating element connected to a local thermostat that controls the temperature of all spaces to 18o C.
• The element type shall be Compact, finned, mineral filled sheathed element.
• Electric radiators shall be controlled via a local temperature stat.
Radiators shall have the following controls made available: o Digitally controlled.
• On completion full balancing and commissioning results shall be provided as a condition to Practical Completion.
• The Developer shall provide commissioning certificates proving the correct operation of the variable speed drives per apartment on handover of the building.
These certificates shall record sample valve configurations and associated volume flow rate readings.
With this strategy in place all doors shall have a minimum of a 10mm undercut to allow air to be pulled from the space
• To increase ventilation wall vents with airflow regulators within the façade make up are required to be placed in the kitchen/living and bedrooms of the dwellings which are all
The wall vents for dwellings shall be capable of achieving a minimum of 52l/s of ventilation per dwelling to feed the decentralised heating plant (where applicable) with sufficient fresh air.
• Permanent ventilation to internal circulation spaces is required to reduce the overheating risk during extended periods of warm weather.
The ventilation strategy shall provide an air change rate of 1 air changes per hour even when the apartment units are unoccupied for extended periods.
• A secure manually operable ventilator shall be provided to the living spaces of all dwellings that allows occupiers to keep a minimum level of purge ventilation when the dwelling is unoccupied.
The free area of this ventilator shall be a minimum of 0.09m2
• The tank room shall contain an external louvre with associated in line fan and associated airtight damper (to 5m3 /m2 /hr at 50 Pa and with an insulation value of 0.4W/m2 K or better).
This damper and fan shall be linked to a temperature sensor and shall open when the temperature within the tank room rises in order to prevent overheating of the water tank.
The louver shall be fitted with an insect mesh.
When temperature within the tank room rises to 20o C or above the fan shall turn on operating at 100l/s for a set time of 30 minutes or when the temperature returns to a level less than 20o C
• Ducts exiting the building shall be protected from unwanted air leakage as follows: o Ducts of 150Dia or less shall be fitted with airtight backdraught dampers.
o Ducts to internal toilets shall not be provided with shut off or backdraught dampers.
• All exiting ducts shall be insulated up to and including their air leakage dampers and passive ducts shall be fully insulated.
• The kitchen canopies shall be ducted to the external walls of the dwellings they serve.
• All sections of ductwork that pass between fire zones without the application of a smoke damper shall be fire rated and smoke tight.
The associated ductwork shall be installed, tested, and certified to DW144 Class C.
• Where the building contains fire dampers or fire smoke damper, they shall comply fully with the building fire certificate.
All fire and fire/smoke dampers shall be motorized to allow automated routine testing and the spring closed type.
• Particular care shall be taken to ensure that the system design and components installed do not compromise the ability of the building to achieve its stringent air tightness target.
• Passive smoke ductwork shall be required as necessary to comply with the buildings fire certificate.
Smoke duct shall terminate into appropriate areas a minimum of 5metres from fire escapes, air intakes or openable windows / doors.
• Duct work shall be fire and smoke rated; smoke ventilation shall be in compliance with BS 9999.

Smoke duct work shall be fire rated and smoke tight with 60minutes Insulation and 60 minutes Integrity unless specifically agreed differently with the Fire Department and in compliance with the fire certificate.
The associated ductwork shall be installed, tested, and certified to DW144 Class C.
• Where smoke shafts are provided the smoke shaft vents/hatches shall be automatically resetting, and a flow forge platform provided at each level.
• Spaces shall achieve the following air change rates.

• The development shall comply with the Employer’s taxonomy and sustainability requirements set in the Procedures Manual Two industry best practice assessments shall be used to evaluate the building design and assess the overheating risk: • CIBSE TM59 o CIBSE TM59 overheating analysis which states that bedrooms may only exceed 26°C for 1% of the year's sleeping hours (10pm-7am).
All other occupied rooms - which includes the bedrooms between 7am and 10pm - may only exceed 26°C for 3% of annual hours.
o Such criteria must be satisfied as a pre-condition to any call off contract being awarded.

o Climate data for thermal modelling of buildings – Met Eireann – The Irish Meteorological Service • Thermal Modelling o Thermal modelling shall be conducted in accordance with CIBSE AM11 Building Energy and Environmental Modelling.
If required by the Procedures Manual, thermal modelling shall also be carried out during the Defects Liability Period.
The software shall also be certified in accordance with the ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 140-2007 “Standard Method of Test for Evaluation of Building Energy Analysis Computer Programs”.
• Handheld fire extinguishers and signage shall be provided throughout the circulation areas of the building as required to comply fully with IS291:2015 and are to be manufactured to IS EN3:1996.
• Furthermore, fire blankets shall be installed in each apartment kitchen.
• The Developer shall allow for mounting all extinguishers and associated signage.

The dry riser systems shall be designed and installed in accordance with BS9990.
They shall be located 750mm above floor level and be complete with an instantaneous coupling to BS 336, a protecting cap with chain, and a leather strap and padlock.

rule_text: • General o All controls within dwellings shall be contained and controlled within the apartment.
o BMS shall only control the landlord plant such as pumps (circulation and civil pumps), fans, legionella test kit or similar critical equipment associated with landlord plant.
Furthermore, all electrical and water metering shall be linked to the BMS system for monitoring including the photovoltaic systems.
The BMS panel shall be located within the plantroom and shall be linked to the fire alarm as part of the cause- and-effect strategy including emergency lighting Intelligent Testing.
o The Developer shall appoint a controls specialist as their domestic sub-contractor to carry out the control’s installation.

The use of a controls specialist in no way limits the responsibilities of the mechanical specialist who shall take full responsibility for the correct installation, testing, demonstration and functioning of the buildings controls system.

• Controls Specialist o The Developer shall ensure that a Controls Specialist is appointed for the project must meet the following criteria: ▪ The company carrying out the installation must have had an office in Ireland for at least five years.
▪ The Controls Specialist must have previously completed at least ten projects of a similar type and complexity and be able to provide reference contacts for five of same on request.

▪ The Controls Specialist appointed for the project must provide an Engineer with at least five years’ experience in controls to carry out the programming and demonstration of the controls system to the Employer’s Representative and client.
The CV of the individual who will be responsible for the system programming must be forwarded to the Employer’s Representative prior to commencing work on the controls installation.
o All equipment provided must include all appropriate accessories, licences etc.
o The company must offer a controls system capable of providing a web-based user interface that will allow the user to access the system through the computer network.
o The web-based network shall not rely on Java as security updates have been shown to cause difficulties for end users.
o The controls provider must be licenced to supply and install the systems being installed by the system manufacturer.

• The Developer is required to meet the Employer’s taxonomy and sustainability requirements set in the Procedures Manual and at a minimum achieve and provide an “A2” or “A1” certificate and improve upon the current Part L building regulations by 10% to align with the EU Taxonomy requirements.
• The BER must be carried out by an accredited non-domestic energy assessor registered by SEAI.

• Whilst the BER rating must be submitted to Sustainable Energy Authority Ireland (SEAI), the Developer shall compile and present this to the Technical Monitor for agreement in accordance with the following requirements prior to submission in the form of a
• The application for the BER rating shall be submitted at least eight weeks prior to Practical Completion.
• The rating shall be fully traceable as to all inputs into the BER (NEAP) software provided by the Sustainable Energy Authority of Ireland (SEAI).
The information shall contain the details of each input which is not a default input.
• The Developer shall provide a complete electrical services installation which is fit for purpose and which meets the requirements of this Specification, including the following.

• The words “complete electrical services installation” shall mean not only the major items of plant and apparatus described in this Specification, but also the incidental sundry accessories and components necessary for the complete execution of the Works and for the proper and safe operation of the installation, whether or not these sundry accessories or components are mentioned in detail in the Contract.
Where a service serves more than one dwelling it shall be routed within Landlord areas only
10101 The Developer shall provide the complete, co-ordinated design and installation of the electrical systems within the building.

This shall include liaising with the various specialist suppliers such as the Façade, Architectural, Fire, or Mechanical systems to ensure that all power and / or control wiring required for any of these specialist systems is included.
Where a European or international standard has been modified or appended for use in Ireland, the modified or appended version shall apply.
Irish Standards shall take preference in all cases, provided that no conflict exists between the Standard and the particular requirements of the Systems Specification.
In such circumstances the Client’s representative shall decide on which standard takes precedence.

• The works to which this Specification relates must comply with the current issue of the following: o The Building Regulations o The Building Control Regulations (BCAR) o Safety, Health and Welfare at Work Act o The Asbestos Regulations o Local Authorities By-Laws and Regulations o Water Supply Authority’s requirements o Electricity Supply Authority’s requirements o Fire Officers’ Requirements o IS 10101 National Rules for Electrical Installations • The works shall be carried out in accordance with the requirements and regulations of all relevant local authorities, fire brigades, and water, gas, electricity authorities.
Authorities shall be notified as necessary about the connection of utilities.
• An electronic operating and maintenance manual and associated “as installed” drawings archive shall be procured from a specialist documentation company by the Developer.
• This manual must be prepared in advance of practical completion and handed to and demonstrated to the Employer on completion of the building.
• The Safety File shall be compatible with and be fully integrated with the Employer’s standard Safety File software platform (which is currently based on DFM Systems technology).
• Divert any existing underground services that must be moved to facilitate the construction of the building.
An appropriate clear zone shall be provided around the perimeter of the building line.
• All road opening, excavation, back filling, temporary and permanent reinstatement must be carried out in accordance with Legal Requirements, including Local Authority specifications.
• All ducting must be kept clean, and its ends sealed with a plastic cap during storage and following installation to prevent ingress of grit or stones which can damage cables.
• All ducting installed shall be provided with 8kN polypropylene draw rope secured at both ends in the duct.
Ducting shall be solid wall uPVC, 3.8mm minimum wall thickness and be in accordance with the various utility provider’s specifications.
ESB Mini-Pillars chambers shall be pre-cast concrete type, block-built types are not acceptable.
• EIR Telecoms / Broadband o It shall be the responsibility of the Developer to excavate trenches, lay ducts and construct cable chambers as necessary for the Eir Telecoms / Broadband services.
The Developer shall be responsible for liaising with Eir concerning all aspects of the installation including, installation timelines, cabling requirements etc.
The Eir installation shall be in accordance with the current revision of Eir Builder’s Specification for open Eir’s Telecoms Infrastructure Requirements.
o A ‘Fibre to The Premises’ (FTTP) solution shall be provided to all residential units.
o Fibre shall be routed from the main Telecoms room and distributed vertically within each riser to the apartments.
o Space shall be allowed within the riser for EIR equipment, including fibre splitters.
o Electronic ‘Type II’ surge protection shall be provided on all incoming Telecoms and TV services, incoming water mains services, CCTV services, intruder alarm and fire alarm services etc.

• TV Services o The Developer shall be responsible for the provision of open-source TV services for all residential units including liaising with TV service providers concerning all aspects of the installation including, installation timelines, cabling requirements etc.
o Fibre shall be routed from the main comms room and distributed vertically within each riser to apartments.
o Space shall be allowed within the risers for the TV service provider’s active equipment, including fibre splitters.

• The electrical infrastructure shall comprise a main ESB offloading / LV panel, connecting to a Main Distribution Board (MDB), subsequently connecting to Sub Distribution Boards, which in turn connect to final circuits.
• All residential units shall be provided with individual whole current single-phase 80A/63A ESB metered connections.
• To ensure access for ESB Networks, the Developer shall install an ESB Networks ’KEY SAFE’, in the external wall of the LV switch room next to the door.
The Developer shall provide and house in the key safe, keys to LV switch room door.
• Multi-function metering (MFM) tied in to BMS shall be provided on all main supplies to Landlord SDBs, main plant, and residential unit customer circuit breakers as per CIBSE TM: 39.

Assembly: a) Uni-Strut Frame Mounted b) Bottom Entry, Top Exit c) All panel sections providing direct access to live assemblies shall be openable only with a special tool d) All panel sections accessing shrouded MCB’s shall be provided with a handle for opening Switchboard Classification: Form 3b compartmentalised in accordance with IS EN 61439-2 Enclosure Protection: IP 41 Enclosure Fire Rating: 60 Minutes Fault Level: 25kA for 1.0 second • RCD units shall be the thermal/magnetic protection as Type 1,2,3,4 as specified, rated at 30mA with a short circuit breaking capacity of 9kA, and shall be combined with the final sub-circuit MCB as an MCB/RCD (RCBO) protective device.
All RCD units shall be equipped with a test button to simulate operation of the device.
All RCBO’s shall be B or C type as appropriate.
• In addition to the above, Arc Fault Detection Devices (AFDD’s) shall also be installed on all final single-phase circuits not exceeding 230V.
Arc fault detection devices shall comply with IS EN 62606 and shall be individual combined MCB/RCD/AFDD units.
• 25% spare capacity for future expansion including circuit breakers shall be provided on the main and sub-distribution switchboards.

• A system of galvanised steel cable tray/ladder and trunking/conduit shall be installed to distribute all mains, sub-mains, general and emergency lighting, power, fire alarm, and mechanical services control wiring throughout the building.
Separate wiring systems shall be segregated in accordance with the National Rules for Electrical Installations.

Fire resistant cables shall be supported on a system that has an approval of equal duration to that of the cables it is supporting.

rule_text: • Supply and install Single phase 230V, 7.0kW Electric Vehicle charging units in the Car Park as required to comply with both the planning permission and current Building Regulations.

• The design and installation of the EV Charging infrastructure must be future proofed to have capacity for EV charging capability for (i) all remaining carparking spaces in the development (ii) micromobility vehicles, scooters, bikes etc in a pre-agreed secure area external to any residential block.
The design must accommodate the possibility of the Employer outsourcing the operation of the EV charging infrastructure, including the EV charging points to a third-party operator.

• The design and installation shall be compliant with the prevailing National Standards Authority of Ireland (NSAI) National Rules for Electrical Installations, the International Electrotechnical Commission standards including 62196- Vehicle Connectors, 61851- Electric Vehicle Conductive Charging, 15118- Road Vehicles V2G, 14443- RFID and also the Open Charge Alliance (OCA) open standards including the Open Charge Point Protocol (OCPP) and the Open Smart Charging Protocol (OSCP) and the Open Charge Point Interface protocol (OCPI).
• Each single / dual outlet charger post shall be of robust design and vandal resistant and be suitable for use in an unsupervised environment.
Steel protection bands/bollards shall also be provided around the charging points to protect from vehicle impact.
• A Dynamic Load Management system shall be provided to allow the load to be managed when there is not sufficient electrical capacity available to have all EV charge points available simultaneously.

The system shall also be capable of configuring to allow high priority points remain on full charge, low priority points on a permanent low charge rate and remaining points adjusting as per supply and demand.
• The generator shall be equipped with automatic mains failure changeover facility and will have capacity to provide 8 hours back-up service at full load.

• The generator shall be complete with a Sound Attenuated Weatherproof Canopy to achieve the following noise levels; o 79 dbA at 1.0m in free field conditions o 69 dbA at 7.0m in free field conditions • Access to the control panel end & on both sides for maintenance shall be required.
o The generator supplier shall include in his bid for the supply of one complete set of spare filters.
The filters shall be handed over to the Employer when the generator is fully commissioned.

• Warranty o The generator supplier shall guarantee the generator set and all associated equipment and systems for a minimum period of 12 months from the date of hand-over on site, and completion of the electrical installation.

• The lighting systems shall be designed and installed in accordance with the relevant SLL Guides to include detailed co-ordination with the building structure to ensure that all areas of the building achieve the illumination and uniformity levels required to comply with the relevant SLL Guides and Part M Building Regulations.

• Within the apartments, the lighting shall generally comprise ceiling roses for the future provision of pendant fittings by the tenants, with recessed IP rated LED downlighters in the Kitchen and Bathrooms.
• Any escape stair lighting shall be on a separate lighting circuit from the supply to any other part of the escape route.
• Any lighting diffuser installed in an escape lobby which has a polycarbonate or acrylic louvre must have a BS999:2017 TP(a) rating.

Diffuser Material Polycarbonate c/w Narrow Distribution, TP(a) rating Ingress Protection Rating (IP) IP44 for Toilets, IP65 for Plantrooms / External Wattage (W) To be provided for all Luminaires Total Wattage Including Losses (CW) To be provided for all Luminaires Luminaire Lumens (LL) lm @350mA Each individual LED fitting must be tested to determine the exact luminaire lumen output (LL).
Efficiency - LL/CW 125 LL/W Warm White 3000k / 135 LL/W Neutral White 4000k @700mA Must be stated as Luminaire Lumens per Circuit Watt (Including all losses) (LL/CW) Light Output Ratio (LOR)
The following shall be confirmed; Who is the warrantor?
context: 2 SDCM  Initial Colour Tolerance: < 2  SDCM (+/- 50K). Colour  Tolerance after 50,000hrs: < 3  SDCM (+/- 175K)

rule_text: EN 55015 Yes - Declaration of Conformity Please provide accompanying documentation EN 61547 Yes - Declaration of Conformity Please provide accompanying documentation EN6100-3-2: Harmonics Yes - Declaration of Conformity Please provide accompanying documentation EN60598-1 Luminaires: General Requirements & Tests Yes - Declaration of Conformity Please provide accompanying documentation EN60598-2-1: Fixed General Proposed Luminaires Yes - See Declaration of Conformity Please provide accompanying documentation IEC 62722-2-1:2014 Yes - See Declaration of Conformity Please provide accompanying documentation IES LM 79-08 Test reports must be provided for all luminaires proposed.
• Lighting Controls o An automatic lighting control system comprising of dimmable control daylight/movement PIR’s and Auto/Off switches shall be provided in all circulation areas.

• Illumination Levels o Average minimum working plane illumination levels shall be as follows: Space Illumination Level (Lux) Uniformity Entrance Lobby 200 0.40 Landlord Internal Circulation Areas 100 0.40 Apartment Internally 100 0.20 Plant Rooms 300 0.40 Underground Car Parks 75 0.40 Underground Car Park Entrance Ramp
After one year from practical handover the Employer must exercise its responsibility to ensure a contract is in place for the servicing and maintenance of this life safety system.
o An intelligent addressable self-testing system shall also be provided.
The system must be modular and have the capacity to be extended in the future.
The system shall be a configurable PERC type as described in the latest IS 3217 and EN62034 standards.
The system shall consist of streetlights, lantern type fittings and robust wall mounted fittings around the building perimeter and on balconies.
o All external lighting shall be 3000K maximum with no up-light element to ensure compliance with any potential Ecological requirements.
o The external lighting installation shall be zoned as outlined below to allow flexibility in its operation, and also to conserve energy.

• Public Lighting o If required, the electrical specialist shall be responsible for the design and installation of a public lighting scheme to illuminate new footpaths/access roads outside the boundary of the main site.
The electrical specialist shall be responsible for the supply & install new red 125mm underground ducting, column bases, luminaires and ESB micro-pillars for public area street lighting installation.
This shall include all works associated with making the ESB Networks NC4 application for the un-metered connection and shall be installed in accordance with the local Co.
• An open architecture Security Management System shall be provided to function as an electronic access control system and shall integrate alarm monitoring, CCTV, digital
A modular and network-enabled architecture shall allow maximum versatility for tailoring secure and dependable access and alarm monitoring solutions.
• The Security Management System control at a central computer location shall be under the control of a single software package and shall provide full integration of all components.

o Reliability; the system shall use distributed architecture so that all cardholder, visitor, and asset access decisions are made locally at the Intelligent System Controller (ISC), cardholders and access rights are automatically loaded after each change.

• The performance of all structured cabling infrastructure for the security systems shall meet ISO 11801, ISO 60603-7-5, ISO 61156-5, IS EN 50173-1, IS EN50310 standards operating at frequencies up to 500Mhz, supporting Voice, Data & Video applications at data rates of up to 10Gbit/s to full 100m channel requirements.
o Rebated mortise solenoid door locks with proximity card release shall be provided.
Include for all Access Control Reader Units, locking mechanisms, Power Supply Units, 12V AC Relay Units, and cabling as required.
The electric locking units shall be heavy duty with a holding force of 12kN suitable for a hardwood timber door and have local key over-ride.

o Locks shall be as follows or equivalent; • Restricted areas: Assa Abloy EL561 • Higher traffic secure areas: Assa Abloy EL560 o The proximity cards shall be DESFire key-fob or card type which can be individually programmed to allow access through all or selected doors.
o The access control shall be disabled by the fire alarm system on activation of a fire alarm.
• Intercom System o A Part M compliant IP Audio Intercom system shall be provided at all main entrances and shall be linked to each residential unit.
o All external Intercom Units shall be IP54 and IK10 rated.
o The system shall be fully integrated with the Access Control System.

• CCTV System o A fully digital IP based PoE (Power over Ethernet) closed circuit television system via category 6A cabling for video signalling shall be provided to cover all public circulation areas including at bins stores, bike stores, underground carparks, entrance and exit doors, and post boxes.
o All cameras shall be colour, capable of day / night operation.

The following minimum standards shall also apply:- • Internal Cameras: Vandal Resistant Fixed IP 2.0 Megapixel • External Cameras: Vandal Resistant Fixed IP 4.0 Megapixel o The monitoring and recording equipment shall consist of a network-based video recorder capable of storing the information from all cameras included on the drawings for 31 days at 30 FPS.

22” monitor shall also be provided to support up to 1920 x 1080 resolutions, high contrast ratio 1000:1, 120Hz motion technology, BNC input, HDMI input and a remote control that can be used on both monitor and DVR.
o The supply and installation of appropriate GDPR warning signage shall be provided at all entrances to the building.
o All Cameras must be ONVIF compliant allowing; • Interoperability – products from various manufacturers can be used in the same systems and “speak the same language”.

• The Landlord controlled areas of this project shall be served by an open protocol analogue addressable fire detection and alarm system in compliance with EN54, to support Morley-IAS, Apollo XP95, or Hochiki ESP Protocols, in accordance with the following specifications.
Each individual component shall comply with its relevant EN54 standard.
• The fire alarm system must be fully compliant with EN54-13 as well as all other individual EN54 standards.
• The fire alarm installation shall comply with I.S.
• All Residential Units shall be provided with combined optical smoke or heat detector with integrated sounder and visual indicator.
The system shall be a Grade D, category LD1 system in accordance with BS 5839-6 or as specified by the Fire Consultant.
• Mains operated smoke and heat detectors shall be fed via lighting circuit.
• The Landlord system shall be extended into each Residential Unit in the form of a combined heat detector with integrated sounder installed in the main Hallway of the unit.
• Fire Detection Systems o Smoke detectors shall be optical type.
Multi-sensors (optical / heat / C0) shall be provided where false alarms are likely such as outside shower rooms / bedrooms / kitchens.
o The fire alarm cabling shall be installed in the same manner throughout i.e.
o All access-controlled doors shall de-energise and release in the event of fire alarm activation.
All interfaces with ancillary mechanical or safety systems must operate using energised normally closed contacts to ensure that these systems will fail safe upon activation of the fire alarm system.
After one year from practical handover the Employer must exercise its responsibility to ensure a contract is in place for the servicing and maintenance of this life safety system.

• Emergency Voice Communication System o A disabled refuge system with numerous call points shall be installed where required by the Fire Consultant in accordance with BS 5839 Part 9, BS9999 & BS8300 and consist of Type B outstations which communicate with a master station.
• A Solar Photovoltaic (PV) system shall be provided to offset the Landlord space electrical consumption if required to meet the Part L non-domestic renewable energy ratio requirements.

• The PV System shall include all required components for a fully functional PV system including all PV panels, supports, containment, cabling, invertors, associated switchgear and all required components.

The PV system shall be a building integrated and grid- connected system and operate in parallel with the grid network need to include meter with automated reporting function for transmission over landlord wi-fi so we can track energy produced.
o The PV panels shall have a 25-year performance warranty and a 10-year product warranty as a minimum.
The maximum annual power loss under the warranty after the first year must be less than 1%.
o Modules shall have a power warranty of at least 90% after 10 years and at least
o The inverter shall be selected based on the following; • Rated Power: The Inverter rating shall be 75-80% of the array rating.

rule_text: • Lightning protection shall be provided in accordance with IS EN 62305 consisting of roof top air terminal network, copper down conductors and linked earth pits.
Where appropriate, use shall be made of metal elements of the roof and structural steel.
All extraneous metal parts on or above roof level shall be bonded to the lightning protection system or protected by Air Terminals.
shall be bonded to the building’s main earth terminal.
All metal incoming services shall also be bonded to the main earthing terminal.
• ESE Streaming devices and associated antennae, such as those described by the Helita system or equivalent shall not be acceptable.
The lightning protection system must comply completely with the abovementioned standards.

• The IS EN 62305 Risk Assessment to determine the level (I to IV) of lightning protection to be provided shall be carried out by the lightning protection specialist and issued to the design team for comment prior to installation.
• All incoming and outgoing cables (of all types) shall be provided with lighting/surge protection devices to IS EN 62305.
The Developer shall ensure allowance for surge protection at all panels within his scope and those provided by others.
• Proper and effective surge protection shall be provided within all electrical switchgear.
• Type Surge I Protection: This shall be provided on the main LV Switchboard.

• The Developer shall be responsible for all design and construction interfaces between the Developers design team mechanical drawings, mechanical specifications, controls points list, Lift drawings and associated specifications making allowance for all wiring in connection with mechanical and lift services required by the mechanical services and controls installations.

• All final connections to mechanical plant from the isolator unit to the particular piece of equipment shall be enclosed in LS0H sheathed flexible metal conduit as “Marshall Tufflex MT Supertube” or equivalent.
Flexible conduit shall be in accordance with IS EN 50086.
All control cabling from the MCC to field items shall be supplied & installed by the Electrical specialist.
• The Developer shall provide a civil and structural solution for the development which is fit for purpose and which meets the requirements of this Specification and the Contract.
• Design Guidelines for SUDS shall be in accordance with the local authority and planning authority.

• The wastewater network that is to serve the proposed development must be designed in accordance with Irish Water’s Code of Practice for Wastewater Infrastructure and the Building Regulations, Part H.
• The watermain network that is to serve the proposed development must be designed in accordance with Irish Water’s Code of Practice for Water Infrastructure.
Auto-tracking will be required to justify access and egress to and from the site as well as within the site for fire tender, refuse, deliveries, and cars.
• Design standards and codes shall include the following: o Current Irish Building Regulations & Technical Guidance Documents (TGD`s) o I.S.
• The building consequence class will be Class 2a/2b in accordance with the Irish Building regulations 2012.

• In relation to proprietary systems and specifically construction methods commonly referred to as Modern Methods of construction each proposed system must have as a minimum the following: o Irish Agreement Certification.

o All proprietary systems must be in compliance with Legal Requirements, must have been proven to be fit for the intended purpose for which they are intended to be used, and must be capable of being serviced, managed and replaced over their intended life cycle.
o The proposed system must be accompanied with the Specialist suite of Certification Sd, Si, and Sc in accordance with the BCAR process.
o The proposed system must comply with the outline list of building design standards as noted above.
• The imposed floor loading must be in accordance with Eurocode EN1991-1-1 Irish Annex, as summarised below.
• Notional Horizontal Loading must be calculated and added to wind loading as per Eurocode requirements.

• The Developer and Professional Team shall ensure that there is sufficient structural capacity to cater for all intended loads including but not limited to green and blue roofs, plant loading and fall arrest systems as maybe proposed.
All products specified must be compatible with the overall system and warranty.
• All buildings must be structurally stable.
• Serviceability performance of floor elements must be coordinated with the acceptable deflection tolerances of the façade.

• The design and construction of any basement works including temporary works must be considered in advance and carried out to avoid damage to adjacent structures, infrastructure, and site boundaries.

The scope of the investigations will be required to evaluate geo-environmental, geotechnical, human health and geotechnical risks and constraints associated with the proposed development and to inform the Employer of the nature of these risks prior to the transfer of the Property to the Employer.
Unless otherwise agreed with the LDA, any investigation reports shall include the LDA as an addressee on such reports.

• Proposed foundation systems for the development will be sufficient to carry all of the proposed loading (as described above) and shall take account of the specific ground conditions at the Property, the proposed construction method and the data retrieved from the site geotechnical reporting.
